ul.li: Describe what an experiment is.
Explain the difference between a between-subjects design and a within-subjects design.
Explain the experimenter expectancy effect.
Explain what a confounded variable is.
Explain what a quasi-experiment is and why a psychologist might use such a design.

body.p: Download a copy of the lecture slides.

p.i: Note: Clicking a link on this page will open the target page in a new tab. Return to this page to continue working through the course.

body.p: Below is a list of terms that were presented in the preceding video and that are important for you to know. Each term is provided with a definition, and sometimes a link to an external resource (e.g., wikipedia entry), to help you better understand the term.

Between-group design: "In the design of experiments, a between-group design is an experiment that has two or more groups of subjects each being tested by a different testing factor simultaneously...The simplest between-group design occurs with two groups; one is generally regarded as the treatment group, which receives the ‘special’ treatment, (that is, is treated with some variable) and the control group, which receives no variable treatment and is used as a reference (prove that any deviation in results from the treatment group is, indeed, a direct result of the variable.)" (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2012, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Between-group_design)

p.em: "In statistics, a confounding variable (also confounding factor, a confound, or confounder) is an extraneous variable in a statistical model that correlates (directly or inversely) with both the dependent variable and the independent variable. A spurious relationship is a perceived relationship between an independent variable and a dependent variable that has been estimated incorrectly because the estimate fails to account for a confounding factor. The incorrect estimation suffers from omitted-variable bias. While specific definitions may vary, in essence a confounding variable fits the following four criteria, here given in a hypothetical situation with variable of interest "V", confounding variable "C" and outcome of interest "O": C is associated (inversely or directly) with O C is associated with O, independent of V C is associated (inversely or directly) with V C is not in the causal pathway of V to O (C is not a direct consequence of V, not a way by which V produces O) The preceding correlation-based definition, however, is metaphorical at best – a growing number of analysts agree that confounding is a causal concept, and as such, cannot be described in terms of correlations nor associations (see causal definition)."

span.em: "The dependent variables represent the output or outcome whose variation is being studied. The independent variables represent inputs or causes, i.e. potential reasons for variation."

body.p: Double-blind design: "A blind — or blinded — experiment is an experiment in which information about the test is masked (kept) from the participant, to reduce or eliminate bias, until after a trial outcome is known. It is understood that bias may be intentional or unconscious, thus no dishonesty is implied by blinding. If both tester and subject are blinded, the trial is called a double-blind experiment." (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2012, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blind_experiment)

Experimenter expectancy effect: "The observer-expectancy effect (also called the experimenter-expectancy effect, expectancy bias, observer effect, or experimenter effect) is a form of reactivity in which a researcher's cognitive bias causes them to subconsciously influence the participants of an experiment. Confirmation bias can lead to the experimenter interpreting results incorrectly because of the tendency to look for information that conforms to their hypothesis, and overlook information that argues against it. It is a significant threat to a study's internal validity, and is therefore typically controlled using a double-blind experimental design. An example of the observer-expectancy effect is demonstrated in music backmasking, in which hidden verbal messages are said to be audible when a recording is played backwards. Some people expect to hear hidden messages when reversing songs, and therefore hear the messages, but to others it sounds like nothing more than random sounds. Often when a song is played backwards, a listener will fail to notice the "hidden" lyrics until they are explicitly pointed out, after which they are obvious." (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2012, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observer-expectancy_effect)

Placebo: "A placebo...is a simulated or otherwise medically ineffectual treatment for a disease or other medical condition intended to deceive the recipient. A person given such an ineffectual treatment will often have a perceived or actual improvement in their condition, a phenomenon commonly called the placebo effect or placebo response. Several different elements contribute to the effect, and the methods of placebo administration may be as important as the administration itself. Placebos are an important methodological tool in medical research. Common placebos include inert tablets (like sugar pills), vehicle infusions, sham surgery, and other procedures based on false information." (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2012, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Placebo)

Quasi-experiment: "A quasi-experiment is an empirical study used to estimate the causal impact of an intervention on its target population. Quasi-experimental research shares similarities with the traditional experimental design or randomized controlled trial, but they specifically lack the element of random assignment to treatment or control." (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2012, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quasi-experiment)

Within-subjects design: "applies the same variations of conditions to each subject to observe the reactions" (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 17, 2012, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Between-group_design)

body.div: The following questions will help you check your understanding of the concepts covered in the previous lecture. You have two attempts to get the right answer. Note that this self check will appear as 'Self-Check 08' on your progress page.

problem.markdown: >>Enrique is interested in studying the effects of long-term cocaine use on various cognitive abilities, such as memory and attention. Because it is considered unethical to give subjects cocaine, instead he must compare current cocaine users to those who have never used cocaine. This study design is known as: << (!) double-blind design (x) quasi-experimental () within-subjects () experimental () correlational
problem.p: Enrique is interested in studying the effects of long-term cocaine use on various cognitive abilities, such as memory and attention. Because it is considered unethical to give subjects cocaine, instead he must compare current cocaine users to those who have never used cocaine. This study design is known as:

choicegroup.label: Enrique is interested in studying the effects of long-term cocaine use on various cognitive abilities, such as memory and attention. Because it is considered unethical to give subjects cocaine, instead he must compare current cocaine users to those who have never used cocaine. This study design is known as:
choicegroup.choice: double-blind design
quasi-experimental
within-subjects
experimental

problem.markdown: >>When interpreting the results of his study comparing long-term cocaine users to healthy controls, Enrique finds that cocaine users have lower scores on many memory tasks. However, he also finds that they have reported more head injuries, poorer long-term diets and higher use of other recreational drugs. These _________ impair his ability to properly assess the relationship between cocaine use and cognitive performance.<< (!) dependent variables (x) confounding variables () experimenter biases () demand characteristics () independent variables
problem.p: When interpreting the results of his study comparing long-term cocaine users to healthy controls, Enrique finds that cocaine users have lower scores on many memory tasks. However, he also finds that they have reported more head injuries, poorer long-term diets and higher use of other recreational drugs. These _________ impair his ability to properly assess the relationship between cocaine use and cognitive performance.

choicegroup.label: When interpreting the results of his study comparing long-term cocaine users to healthy controls, Enrique finds that cocaine users have lower scores on many memory tasks. However, he also finds that they have reported more head injuries, poorer long-term diets and higher use of other recreational drugs. These _________ impair his ability to properly assess the relationship between cocaine use and cognitive performance.
choicegroup.choice: dependent variables
confounding variables
experimenter biases
demand characteristics
independent variables

problem.markdown: >>Ari is interested in determining if taking a particular drug every day reduces the risk of heart attacks. She divides her participants into two groups, with one group taking the drug daily, while the other group takes a placebo daily. After having been in the study for two years, she then measures the rate of heart attacks in each group. This type of study is:<< (!) a cohort design. (x) between-subjects design. () quasi-experimental study. () confounded design. () within-subjects design.
problem.p: Ari is interested in determining if taking a particular drug every day reduces the risk of heart attacks. She divides her participants into two groups, with one group taking the drug daily, while the other group takes a placebo daily. After having been in the study for two years, she then measures the rate of heart attacks in each group. This type of study is:

choicegroup.label: Ari is interested in determining if taking a particular drug every day reduces the risk of heart attacks. She divides her participants into two groups, with one group taking the drug daily, while the other group takes a placebo daily. After having been in the study for two years, she then measures the rate of heart attacks in each group. This type of study is:
choicegroup.choice: a cohort design.
between-subjects design.
quasi-experimental study.
confounded design.
within-subjects design.

vertical.display_name: Statistical Reasoning - Describing Data I: Learning Goals

html.display_name: Statistical Reasoning - Describing Data I: Learning Goals

ul.li: Explain the difference between descriptive and inferential statistics.
Be able to calculate the mean, median, and mode given a data set.
Understand what is meant by the word 'average.'

video.display_name: Part 3, Lecture 2: Statistical Reasoning - Describing Data I

body.p: Download a copy of the lecture slides.

p.i: Note: Clicking a link on this page will open the target page in a new tab. Return to this page to continue working through the course.

body.p: Below is a list of terms that were presented in the preceding video and that are important for you to know. Each term is provided with a definition, and sometimes a link to an external resource (e.g., wikipedia entry), to help you better understand the term.

Central Tendency: "In statistics, a central tendency (or, more commonly, a measure of central tendency) is a central or typical value for a probability distribution. It may also be called a center or location of the distribution. Colloquially, measures of central tendency are often called averages." (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2016, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_tendency)

Descriptive Statistics: "Descriptive statistics are statistics that quantitatively describe or summarise features of a collection of information. Descriptive statistics are distinguished from inferential statistics (or inductive statistics), in that descriptive statistics aim to summarize a sample, rather than use the data to learn about the population that the sample of data is thought to represent...Some measures that are commonly used to describe a data set are measures of central tendency and measures of variability or dispersion. Measures of central tendency include the mean, median and mode, while measures of variability include the standard deviation (or variance), the minimum and maximum values of the variables..." (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2016, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Descriptive_statistics)
Mean: "one measure of the central tendency" (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2016, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean)

Median: "The median is the value separating the higher half of a data sample, a population, or a probability distribution, from the lower half. In simple terms, it may be thought of as the "middle" value of a data set. For example, in the data set {1, 3, 3, 6, 7, 8, 9}, the median is 6, the fourth number in the sample." (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2016, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Median)
Mode: "The mode is the value that appears most often in a set of data." (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2016, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mode_(statistics)

Multimodal distribution: "a multimodal distribution is a continuous probability distribution with two or more modes" (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2016, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multimodal_distribution)

Inferential Statistics: "Inferential statistical analysis infers properties about a population: this includes testing hypotheses and deriving estimates. The population is assumed to be larger than the observed data set; in other words, the observed data is assumed to be sampled from a larger population. Inferential statistics can be contrasted with descriptive statistics. Descriptive statistics is solely concerned with properties of the observed data, and does not assume that the data came from a larger population." (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2016, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_inference)

vertical.display_name: Statistical Reasoning - Describing Data II: Learning Goals

html.display_name: Statistical Reasoning - Describing Data II: Learning Goals

ul.li: Understand the problems with considering measures of central tendency on their own.
Be able to calculate the range, variance, and standard deviation given a data set.
Understand the meaning of a correlation coefficient and a coefficient of determination.

video.display_name: Part 3, Lecture 3: Statistical Reasoning - Describing Data II

body.p: Download a copy of the lecture slides.

p.i: Note: Clicking a link on this page will open the target page in a new tab. Return to this page to continue working through the course.

body.p: Below is a list of terms that were presented in the preceding video and that are important for you to know. Each term is provided with a definition, and sometimes a link to an external resource (e.g., wikipedia entry), to help you better understand the term.

Correlation coefficient: "A correlation coefficient is a number that quantifies some type of correlation and dependence, meaning statistical relationships between two or more random variables or observed data values." (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2016, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Correlation_coefficient)

Range: "The range is the size of the smallest interval which contains all the data and provides an indication of...dispersion." (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2016, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Range_(statistics)

Standard deviation: "In statistics, the standard deviation...is a measure that is used to quantify the amount of variation or dispersion of a set of data values. A low standard deviation indicates that the data points tend to be close to the mean (also called the expected value) of the set, while a high standard deviation indicates that the data points are spread out over a wider range of values. The standard deviation of a random variable, statistical population, data set, or probability distribution is the square root of its variance." (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2016, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_deviation)

Variance: "variance...measures how far a set of (random) numbers are spread out from their mean...The variance is the square of the standard deviation" (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2016, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Variance)

p.em: "In statistics...variability...denotes how stretched or squeezed a distribution...is. Common examples of measures of [variability] are the variance, standard deviation"

ul.li: Describe the purpose of using inferential statistics.
Explain how sampling procedures can impact inferential statistics.
Explain what is meant by statistical significance.
Explain the difference between statistical significance and practical significance.

video.display_name: Part 3, Lecture 4: Statistical Reasoning - Making Inferences

body.p: Download a copy of the lecture slides.

p.i: Note: Clicking a link on this page will open the target page in a new tab. Return to this page to continue working through the course.

body.p: Below is a list of terms that were presented in the preceding video and that are important for you to know. Each term is provided with a definition, and sometimes a link to an external resource (e.g., wikipedia entry), to help you better understand the term.

Sample: "a data sample is a set of data collected and/or selected from a statistical population by a defined procedure. The elements of a sample are known as sample points, sampling units or observations. Typically, the population is very large, making a census or a complete enumeration of all the values in the population is either impractical or impossible. The sample usually represents a subset of manageable size. Samples are collected and statistics are calculated from the samples so that one can make inferences or extrapolations from the sample to the population." (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2016, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sample_(statistics))

Statistical inference: "Statistical inference is the process of deducing properties of an underlying distribution by analysis of data. Inferential statistical analysis infers properties about a population: this includes testing hypotheses and deriving estimates. The population is assumed to be larger than the observed data set; in other words, the observed data is assumed to be sampled from a larger population. Inferential statistics can be contrasted with descriptive statistics. Descriptive statistics is solely concerned with properties of the observed data" (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2016, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_inference)

Statistical population: "In statistics, a population is a set of similar items or events which is of interest for some question or experiment. In statistical inference, a subset of the population (a statistical sample) is chosen to represent the population in a statistical analysis. If a sample is chosen properly, characteristics of the entire population that the sample is drawn from can be estimated from corresponding characteristics of the sample." (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2016, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_population)

Statistical significance: "In statistical hypothesis testing, statistical significance (or a statistically significant result) is attained when a p-value is less than the significance level...The p-value is the probability of obtaining at least as extreme results given that the null hypothesis is true whereas the significance level...is the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis given that it is true...The term significance does not imply importance and the term statistical significance is not the same as research, theoretical, or practical significance. For example, the term clinical significance refers to the practical importance of a treatment effect." (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2016, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_significance)

T-test: "A t-test...can be used to determine if two sets of data are significantly different from each other." (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2016, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Student%27s_t-test)

ul.li: Understand the limitations of laboratory research in predicting the behavior of individuals.
Explain what is meant by the term WEIRD as it pertains to psychological studies.
Understand the importance of culture and gender in psychological research.
Describe the set of standard procedures used to protect human participants during experiments.

body.p: Download a copy of the lecture slides.

p.i: Note: Clicking a link on this page will open the target page in a new tab. Return to this page to continue working through the course.

body.p: Below is a list of terms that were presented in the preceding video and that are important for you to know. Each term is provided with a definition, and sometimes a link to an external resource (e.g., wikipedia entry), to help you better understand the term.

Confidentiality: "Confidentiality involves a set of rules or a promise that limits access or places restrictions on certain types of information." (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2016, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confidentiality)
Debriefing: "Debriefing is a process of...receiving an explanation" (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2016, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Debriefing)

Informed consent: "Informed consent is a process for getting permission before conducting a[n]...intervention on a person." (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2016, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Informed_consent)

WEIRD: "In 2010, a group of researchers reported a systemic bias in psychology studies towards WEIRD ("western, educated, industrialized, rich and democratic") subjects. Although only 1/8 people worldwide fall into the WEIRD classification, the researchers claimed that 60–90% of psychology studies are performed on WEIRD subjects." (In Wikipedia. Retrieved on August 10, 2016, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychology)

() Psychological principles are often good at predicting the behavior of groups of individuals. () Psychological research could be limited by its overreliance on college students as experimental subjects.

discussion.display_name: Part 3, Video: Deception in Psychological Research: Discussion

div.p: In these AP® Psychology courses, you will be asked to grade other students discussion questions and, in later courses, their free response answers for their final exam. The major purpose of these peer grading activities is to critically evaluate how others are answering the questions so that you might improve your own responses.

The peer response activity has two questions, each of which has two steps. First read the question and provide a written response in the text box below it. Once you are done, save your answer and then submit to move on to the next step. In step 2, you will review five answers submitted by other students in the class. You will then repeat this process for discussion question 2.
Note that these discussion questions will appear as 'Discussion 02' on your progress page.

prompt.description: Dr. Marks argues that within-subject (WS) designs are the most sensible for research, whereas Dr. Turner makes a case for between-subject (BS) designs. Make a case for one and carefully critique the other.

criterion.name: Ideas
criterion.label: Completion
criterion.prompt: Does the student make a reasonable attempt at providing a thoughtful response?

option.name: Poor
option.label: Thoughtful Response
option.explanation: The student makes a reasonable attempt at providing a thoughtful response.

option.name: Fair
option.label: Not a Thoughtful Response
option.explanation: The student does not make a reasonable attempt at providing a thoughtful response.

rubric.feedbackprompt:
How well does the student's answer compare to the thoughtful vs. non-thoughtful sample answers? Provide feedback.
Thoughtful answer: Pro-WS. WS designs require fewer people because everyone participates in all of the conditions, which is easier and more convenient. You are also examining the effect in the same person, eliminating the between-group differences that exist to some degree. BS designs require more participants and add that degree of variability.
Pro-BS. BS designs are faster because you can study both groups simultaneously, which is very convenient. You also have a true control group that was not “tainted” by exposure to another condition. WS designs may be slower and may have bleedover (“tainted”).
Non-thoughtful answer: Both designs are useful depending on the goal of the research and so it depends very much on the exact situation.
rubric.feedback_default_text: I think that this response is thoughtful/non-thoughtful because...

prompt.description: Sampling requires us to make inferences about what might be true in the population and unfortunately, inferences are subject to error. Why do we continue to sample despite this possibility?

criterion.name: Ideas
criterion.label: Completion
criterion.prompt: Does the student make a reasonable attempt at providing a thoughtful response?

option.name: Poor
option.label: Thoughtful Response
option.explanation: The student makes a reasonable attempt at providing a thoughtful response.

option.name: Fair
option.label: Not a Thoughtful Response
option.explanation: The student does not make a reasonable attempt at providing a thoughtful response.

rubric.feedbackprompt:
How well does the student's answer compare to the thoughtful vs. non-thoughtful sample answers? Provide feedback.
Thoughtful answer: The fact of the matter is that it is very expensive and resource-intensive to examine the entire population and, depending on what the population is, it might not even be possible. We accept the trade-off because if we can get a reasonable understanding of the behavior of a population without asking everything, it helps more than it hurts.
Non-thoughtful answer: Research is difficult and if we can take an easier route to get the job done, that just makes sense.
rubric.feedback_default_text: I think that this response is thoughtful/non-thoughtful because...

p.i: Note: Clicking a link on this page will open the target page in a new tab. Return to this page to continue working through the course.

div.p: The following is a collection of online resources that you may find helpful for understanding some of the content in Part 1 of this course.
The Power of the Placebo Effect. A great animation exploring the mystery of placebos.
Descriptive Statistics. Great practice on differentiating between mode, median, and mean.
Standard Deviation. How to calculate a standard deviation step-by-step, for those interested in learning.
Populations and Samples. A quick summary of the differences between a population and sample.
Research Ethics. A succinct summary on research ethics within psychology, from informed consent to confidentiality.

div.p: Please note that the following quiz questions use a format that is comparable to that of the multiple choice questions on the AP® Psychology exam.
For each question you will have one attempt.
Note that this quiz will appear as 'Quiz 03' on your progress page.

problem.markdown: >>Which of the following designs is between-subjects?<< (!) A group of participants studies using their normal strategy, and then switches to the Cornell Method, with a dependent measure of course performance (x) A group of participants takes an Alzheimer’s medication, and a different group takes a placebo, with a dependent measure of memory performance () A group of participants goes on a gluten-free diet, and then later goes on a vegan diet, with a dependent measure of body mass index () A group of participants listens to classical music, and later to classic rock (conditions counterbalanced), with a dependent measure of blood pressure () A group of participants sleeps eight hours per night for one week, and then six hours for the next week, with a dependent measure of alertness via a computer task

A group of participants listens to classical music, and later to classic rock (conditions counterbalanced), with a dependent measure of blood pressure
A group of participants sleeps eight hours per night for one week, and then six hours for the next week, with a dependent measure of alertness via a computer task

problem.markdown: >>A concern with within-subjects design is that:<< (!) Looking at the same person over time lacks a necessary longitudinal component (x) Even if counterbalancing is used, the experimenter should be certain that any manipulation has worn off before starting the second condition () While practice effects are no longer an issue, the placebo effect becomes a primary concern () There is no possibility of a control group, or anything like it () There is very little research funding available for this type of research

Even if counterbalancing is used, the experimenter should be certain that any manipulation has worn off before starting the second condition
While practice effects are no longer an issue, the placebo effect becomes a primary concern
There is no possibility of a control group, or anything like it
There is very little research funding available for this type of research
