p.strong: Each of the 100 questions below is followed by five possible answers. Select the best answer in each case.

div.p: Note: This section should take you 70 minutes (although you won't be penalized for going over that suggested time limit)--that is how much time you would have to complete the 100 multiple choice questions on the AP® Psychology Exam. Accordingly, if you would like to get a sense of how well you are pacing yourself on this multiple choice component of the exam, press the 'start timer' button below.

Also note: This section is worth 83.33% of your grade for the final exam in this course (on the actual AP® Psychology Exam the multiple choice are worth 66.66% of your grade), or 50% of your grade in this course.

body.div: During the AP® Psychology exam, you will have 70 minutes to finish this component of the final exam. A timer has been placed here so you can gauge how long it takes you to complete this portion of the exam. Note that you will not be penalized for going over that time limit in this course (though you would not receive additional time on AP® Psychology exam).

problem.p: Which of the following best resembles a specific, testable and falsifiable hypothesis?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following best resembles a specific, testable and falsifiable hypothesis?
choicegroup.choice: Psychological science is the study of behavior and behavior only
Increased caffeine consumption on an exam day will result in improved test performance
The id, superego and ego are what constitute personality
The purpose of memory is to help us learn from our past mistakes
The soul interacts with the pineal gland to produce consciousness and behavior

problem.p: The field of psychology (or psychological science) is best defined as the

choicegroup.label: The field of psychology (or psychological science) is best defined as the
choicegroup.choice: empirical study of humanity.
scientific study of the mind, the brain and behavior.
experimental study of individuals.
systematic study of human interaction.
theoretical study of the subconscious.

problem.p: A broad explanation or group of explanations for some aspect of the natural world that is consistently supported by evidence over time is known as (a)

choicegroup.label: A broad explanation or group of explanations for some aspect of the natural world that is consistently supported by evidence over time is known as (a)
choicegroup.choice: confound.
scientific theory.
hypothesis.
pseudoscience.
empirical data.

problem.p: A good deal of psychology is considered a social science discipline, meaning that psychological scientists study

choicegroup.label: A good deal of psychology is considered a social science discipline, meaning that psychological scientists study
choicegroup.choice: only behavior.
the mind and behavior.
only the mind.
the soul, the mind, and behavior.
the soul and the mind.

problem.p: The empirical method of study is based on

choicegroup.label: The empirical method of study is based on
choicegroup.choice: guess work.
systematic observation.
careful self-reflection.
extensive amounts of practice.
reasoning based on what you know about the world.

problem.p: Who was the first person to technically be a considered a ‘psychologist’?

choicegroup.label: Who was the first person to technically be a considered a ‘psychologist’?
choicegroup.choice: Wolfgang Köhler
Wilhelm Wundt
Sigmund Freud
William James
Franz Gall

problem.p: To study distractibility, Chloe carefully examines her own subjective experience and carefully documents her experience. This practice is most consistent with which of the following practices?

choicegroup.label: To study distractibility, Chloe carefully examines her own subjective experience and carefully documents her experience. This practice is most consistent with which of the following practices?
choicegroup.choice: functionalism
introspection
gestalt analysis
cognitivism
behavioral neuroscience

problem.p: William James contributed many important things to psychological science. Which of the following was true about him?

choicegroup.label: William James contributed many important things to psychological science. Which of the following was true about him?
choicegroup.choice: He is the author of the textbook that you are using
He was the first American psychologist
He was the first person to conduct psychological experiments
He founded the psychological subfield of structuralism
He was the first psychoanalyst to gain recognition from the scientific community

problem.p: Psychoanalytic theory focuses on ________ and early childhood experiences.

choicegroup.label: Psychoanalytic theory focuses on ________ and early childhood experiences.
choicegroup.choice: a person’s moment-to-moment consciousness
a person’s unconscious
early fetal development
epigenetic interactions
how others shape and scaffold our learning environment

multiplechoiceresponse.label: According to William James, the purpose of psychology was to

choicegroup.choice: interpret dreams.
study the structure and characteristics of the mind.
manipulate human behavior.
study the function of behavior.
determine the subconscious factors that motivated behavior.

problem.p: What is Abraham Maslow best known for?

choicegroup.label: What is Abraham Maslow best known for?
choicegroup.choice: Establishing the principles of classical conditioning
Proposing a hierarchy of human needs that motivate behavior
Developing a framework for analyzing the latent content of dreams
Studying the influence of reinforcement and punishment on behavior
Using computers to model human cognition

problem.p: Which aspect of the scientific method should occur first?

choicegroup.label: Which aspect of the scientific method should occur first?
choicegroup.choice: peer review
developing a hypothesis
data collection
designing your experiment
careful observation

problem.p: Which of the following best exemplifies the empirical method?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following best exemplifies the empirical method?
choicegroup.choice: Friends engage in a spirited debate about whether or not marijuana should be legalized.
Dr. Sarkeesian observes and records how watching cartoons influences heart rate.
A student in a psychology class writes his term paper on whether or not fish feel pain.
A student writes a letter to his professor requesting a change in course policy.
Dr. Hysock-Witham decides to start her course later because so many students arrive late.

problem.p: Char heard from her friends that marijuana use can cure glaucoma so it should be legalized. Char knows that she is biased in favor of marijuana legalization, so she decides to exercise some skepticism about this claim. She researches where her friends got their information, how reliable it is, and what other sources say about legalizing marijuana. Char is

choicegroup.label: Char heard from her friends that marijuana use can cure glaucoma so it should be legalized. Char knows that she is biased in favor of marijuana legalization, so she decides to exercise some skepticism about this claim. She researches where her friends got their information, how reliable it is, and what other sources say about legalizing marijuana. Char is
choicegroup.choice: acting unconsciously.
thinking critically.
hypothesizing.
theorizing.
postulating.

problem.p: Functionalists focused on the function of behavior and

choicegroup.label: Functionalists focused on the function of behavior and
choicegroup.choice: explaining the subconscious.
the operation of the whole mind rather than its individual parts.
the operation of individual parts of the mind.
understanding the id, ego, and superego.
social influences on behavior.

problem.p: Dr. Bogdarian noticed that one of her students addresses her with the word “mother” instead of the word “professor” or “doctor.” Dr. Bogdarian applies the principles of ________, and hypothesizes the student misspoke because he is unconsciously associating her with his mother.

choicegroup.label: Dr. Bogdarian noticed that one of her students addresses her with the word “mother” instead of the word “professor” or “doctor.” Dr. Bogdarian applies the principles of ________, and hypothesizes the student misspoke because he is unconsciously associating her with his mother.
choicegroup.choice: functionalism
psychoanalytic theory
gestalt psychology
behavioralism
structuralism

problem.p: A series of dots arranged in the shape of a face will be perceived as a face, not a series of dots. A psychologist studying this phenomenon is applying the principals of

choicegroup.label: A series of dots arranged in the shape of a face will be perceived as a face, not a series of dots. A psychologist studying this phenomenon is applying the principals of
choicegroup.choice: humanism.
gestalt psychology.
psychoanalytic theory.
structuralism.
behavioralism.

problem.p: I provide Ralph with the positive reinforcement of a candy bar when he does something I like. I punish him by squirting him with a squirt gun when he does something I don’t like. I am applying the principles of ________ in an attempt to modify Ralph’s behavior.

choicegroup.label: I provide Ralph with the positive reinforcement of a candy bar when he does something I like. I punish him by squirting him with a squirt gun when he does something I don’t like. I am applying the principles of ________ in an attempt to modify Ralph’s behavior.
choicegroup.choice: classical conditioning
operant conditioning
functionalism
humanism
observational learning

problem.p: In Maslow’s hierarchy of needs, the ________ include food, water, and shelter.

choicegroup.label: In Maslow’s hierarchy of needs, the ________ include food, water, and shelter.
choicegroup.choice: basic survival needs
comfort objects
higher-level needs
wants
desires

problem.p: Which of the following exemplifies the unconditional positive regard component of client-centered therapy?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following exemplifies the unconditional positive regard component of client-centered therapy?
choicegroup.choice: Boris tells his therapist that that he needs stronger medication and his therapist prescribes it.
Abby tells her therapist that she tripped a small child who got in her way, and her therapist accepts this information without judgment.
Natasha is late for her therapy session and her therapist believes she did this because she unconsciously dislikes therapy.
Xavier receives a hug from the doctor when he arrives on time; he does not get a hug when he arrives late.
Rose’s therapist tells her to hurry up when she is discussing problems she has with her husband.

problem.p: Penelope studies how the structure and function of the nervous system is related to behavior. She is a

choicegroup.label: Penelope studies how the structure and function of the nervous system is related to behavior. She is a
choicegroup.choice: developmental psychologist.
biopsychologist.
humanist.
social psychologist.
clinical psychologist.

problem.p: Peter is interested in pursuing a(n) ________ training program with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention after he receives his PhD, which will allow him to further develop his research on adolescent suicide and broaden his research skills.

choicegroup.label: Peter is interested in pursuing a(n) ________ training program with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention after he receives his PhD, which will allow him to further develop his research on adolescent suicide and broaden his research skills.
choicegroup.choice: industrial
postdoctoral
medical
predoctoral
postgraduate

problem.p: The cognitive revolution created an impetus for psychologists to focus their attention on better understanding

choicegroup.label: The cognitive revolution created an impetus for psychologists to focus their attention on better understanding
choicegroup.choice: emotions and cultural norms that underlie emotional responses.
the mental processes that underlie behavior.
genetics and the evolutionary adaptations that underlie behavior.
stimulus-response relationships.
how psychological disorders can be best be understood.

problem.p: If you show an adult a toy, and then hide it behind a curtain, the adult knows that the toy still exists. However, infants act as if the hidden object no longer exists. What does this situation exemplify?

choicegroup.label: If you show an adult a toy, and then hide it behind a curtain, the adult knows that the toy still exists. However, infants act as if the hidden object no longer exists. What does this situation exemplify?
choicegroup.choice: article blindness
object permanence
developmental theory
perpetuation
introspection

problem.p: Cognitive psychology focuses on studying

choicegroup.label: Cognitive psychology focuses on studying
choicegroup.choice: genetics and the effect of genetics on behavior.
thoughts and their relationship to our experiences and actions.
the effect of culture on perceptual processing.
the effect of gender, race, and class on behavior.
the influences of evolutionary pressures on behavior.

problem.p: Which theorist published work related to the origins of personality?

choicegroup.label: Which theorist published work related to the origins of personality?
choicegroup.choice: Charles Darwin
Sigmund Freud
Jean Piaget
Noam Chomsky
B.F. Skinner

problem.p: Edmund wants to identify relatively consistent patterns of thought and behavior, measure these traits, and determine how these traits interact in a particular context to determine how a person will behave in any given situation. Edmund wants to conduct research in the area of

choicegroup.label: Edmund wants to identify relatively consistent patterns of thought and behavior, measure these traits, and determine how these traits interact in a particular context to determine how a person will behave in any given situation. Edmund wants to conduct research in the area of
choicegroup.choice: development.
personality.
cognition.
perception.
social psychology.

problem.p: Susan wants to study prejudice, attraction, how we explain our own behavior versus how we explain the behavior of others, and how we resolve interpersonal conflicts. Susan should conduct research in the area of

choicegroup.label: Susan wants to study prejudice, attraction, how we explain our own behavior versus how we explain the behavior of others, and how we resolve interpersonal conflicts. Susan should conduct research in the area of
choicegroup.choice: gestalt psychology.
social psychology.
personality psychology.
psychoanalysis.
developmental psychology.

problem.p: Behaviorism focused on making psychology an objective science by

choicegroup.label: Behaviorism focused on making psychology an objective science by
choicegroup.choice: studying how emotional responses influence behavior while deemphasizing the importance of the subconscious.
studying overt behavior and deemphasizing the importance of the mind.
studying implicit motivations for behavior through the use of implicit association tests.
studying the genetic basis for behavior and theorizing how instincts influence behavior.
studying the influence of one’s peers on the individual development of morality.

problem.p: Which of the following is an example of research that someone might conduct in the area of health psychology?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following is an example of research that someone might conduct in the area of health psychology?
choicegroup.choice: How the age of a leader affects the productivity of the group.
Whether people working at a desk are more likely to be overweight.
What personality traits are present more often in men compared to women.
Whether culture influences perception.
How a drug can affect performance on a cognitive task.

problem.p: Which theorist had the most influence in shaping how clinicians interact with people seeking psychotherapy?

choicegroup.label: Which theorist had the most influence in shaping how clinicians interact with people seeking psychotherapy?
choicegroup.choice: Abraham Maslow
Carl Rogers
Wilhelm Wundt
William James
Kurt Koffka

problem.p: Naghmeh wants to focus on the emotional, social, vocational, and health-related outcomes of individuals who are considered psychologically healthy. Which area of psychology should she work in?

choicegroup.label: Naghmeh wants to focus on the emotional, social, vocational, and health-related outcomes of individuals who are considered psychologically healthy. Which area of psychology should she work in?
choicegroup.choice: clinical psychology
counseling psychology
wellness psychology
developmental psychology
biopsychology

problem.p: Select the correctly ordered list of psychological perspectives, with the perspectives ordered from earliest to most recent.

choicegroup.label: Select the correctly ordered list of psychological perspectives, with the perspectives ordered from earliest to most recent.
choicegroup.choice: humanism, behaviorism, structuralism, functionalism
structuralism, functionalism, behaviorism, humanism
humanism, structuralism, functionalism, behaviorism
structuralism, functionalism, humanism, behaviorism
functionalism, humanism, behaviorism, structuralism

problem.p: Which of the following is not involved in critical thinking?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following is not involved in critical thinking?
choicegroup.choice: maintaining an attitude of skepticism
knowing your opinion is correct
making use of logical thinking
recognizing internal biases
asking appropriate questions

problem.p: What do structuralism, Gestalt psychology, and Sigmund Freud all have in common?

choicegroup.label: What do structuralism, Gestalt psychology, and Sigmund Freud all have in common?
choicegroup.choice: They were all concerned with describing and understanding animal behavior.
They were all concerned with describing and understanding one’s inner experience.
They were all concerned with diagnosing and treating psychosis.
They were all concerned with the nature of evil during the Nazi regime.
They were all interested in using rationalism to create knowledge in psychology.

problem.p: Why is psychology considered a social science?

choicegroup.label: Why is psychology considered a social science?
choicegroup.choice: Because psychologists study groups and how groups interact.
Behavior is biological, and our behavior is influenced by our interactions with others.
Because psychology is not considered a hard science.
Behavior is unpredictable, so scientists study it.
Because psychology is focused on understanding the social aspects of human experience.

problem.p: Which of the following is a criticism of structuralism?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following is a criticism of structuralism?
choicegroup.choice: Scientific instruments were not sensitive enough to measure precise reaction times.
The process was highly subjective.
Structuralism was parsimonious.
Wilhelm Wundt falsified his results.
The process did not rely on trained observers.

problem.p: According to Sigmund Freud, all of the following represent ways to access the unconscious mind except through

choicegroup.label: According to Sigmund Freud, all of the following represent ways to access the unconscious mind except through
choicegroup.choice: dream analysis.
the use of reinforcement and punishment.
examination of the first words that come to someone’s mind.
seemingly innocent slips of the tongue.
conversation between a patient and a clinician.

problem.p: Which of the following would be the least interesting to a personality psychologist?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following would be the least interesting to a personality psychologist?
choicegroup.choice: How personality changes (or remains stable) across the lifespan
If non-human animals show emotion under different circumstances
How different personality types might be associated with different patterns of brain activity
Whether a “Type A personality” is linked with any health benefits or risks
Whether personality is something we start with, or something that develops

problem.p: In a study of mate preference differences between men and women that spanned 37 cultures, Buss (1989) found that men value youthful appearance in potential sexual partners more than women. Why might this be?

choicegroup.label: In a study of mate preference differences between men and women that spanned 37 cultures, Buss (1989) found that men value youthful appearance in potential sexual partners more than women. Why might this be?
choicegroup.choice: It was a sampling bias, as there were very few older women involved in the research.
Youthful looks provide fertility clues.
Men prefer women with more sexual experience and history.
Women are not as superficial as men.
A youthful appearance results a more favorable relationship history.

problem.p: In developmental psychology, there is an increasing interest in researching cognitive changes that occur later in life. Which of the following is a leading reason as to why?

choicegroup.label: In developmental psychology, there is an increasing interest in researching cognitive changes that occur later in life. Which of the following is a leading reason as to why?
choicegroup.choice: There is more money available for this research, compared to other developmental work.
Those in developed nations are living longer and advanced age is a risk factor for decline.
The average age of psychology researchers is increasing.
People in developed nations tend to have more respect for the elderly, relatively speaking.
Populations in developing nations are dying sooner compared to developed nations.

problem.p: What do industrial and organizational psychology, health psychology, sport and exercise psychology, forensic psychology, and clinical psychology all have in common?

choicegroup.label: What do industrial and organizational psychology, health psychology, sport and exercise psychology, forensic psychology, and clinical psychology all have in common?
choicegroup.choice: Job growth is the most unstable and unpredictable in these fields.
They are all examples of applied psychology.
They all focus on groups rather than individuals.
They are all areas of psychology that developed in the 21st century.
They are all concerned with adult populations more than children.

problem.p: According to the biopsychosocial model, what determines one’s health?

choicegroup.label: According to the biopsychosocial model, what determines one’s health?
choicegroup.choice: Applying biological principles to the psychology of a healthy social life
The complex interaction of biological, psychological, and social factors
Biological health first, followed by psychological health, and then social health
Social health first, followed by psychological health, and then biological health
The amount you exercise and the quality of your diet

problem.p: What should be changed to make the following sentence true? Sigmund Freud believed that understanding the unconscious mind was critical to understand subconscious behavior.

choicegroup.label: What should be changed to make the following sentence true? Sigmund Freud believed that understanding the unconscious mind was critical to understand subconscious behavior.
choicegroup.choice: The name “Sigmund Freud” should be changed to “Wilhelm Wundt.”
The word “subconscious” should be changed to the word “conscious.”
The word “unconscious” should be changed to the word “conscious.”
The word “understand” should be changed to the word “believing.”
The word “critical” should be changed to “not important.”

problem.p: What was the primary conclusion of Stanley Milgram’s obedience research?

choicegroup.label: What was the primary conclusion of Stanley Milgram’s obedience research?
choicegroup.choice: Everyday behavior can be explained by instincts developed in our ancestral population.
Average people are likely to do harm to others if told to do so by an authority figure.
Our mothers have an enormous impact on the development of our personality.
What we sense and what we perceive varies according to culture, race, and gender.
People adopt societal roles quickly, and explain bad behavior using dispositional variables.

problem.p: Which of the following is a feminist criticism of the science of psychology?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following is a feminist criticism of the science of psychology?
choicegroup.choice: Male psychologists assume that their results do not apply to women.
Male bias exists in science.
Male psychologists do not pay enough attention to partnerships and relationships.
Male psychologists emphasize objective data over subjective data.
Male psychologists refuse to study women.

problem.p: Which of the following is a criticism of evolutionary psychology?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following is a criticism of evolutionary psychology?
choicegroup.choice: It refuses to acknowledge non-genetic factors in determining human behavior.
It places too much emphasis on genetic factors in determining human behavior.
It is too easy to disprove theories developed by evolutionary psychologists.
Theories in evolutionary psychology are not sufficiently specific.
The context that our species developed in simply isn’t relevant to the modern world.

problem.p: Which of the following statements regarding perception is false?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following statements regarding perception is false?
choicegroup.choice: Perception may be influenced by one’s cultural background
Perception is identical between most individuals
Perception may be influenced by one’s previous experiences
Perception may be influenced by where we focus our attention
Perception is complex

problem.p: Behaviorists all focus on

choicegroup.label: Behaviorists all focus on
choicegroup.choice: individual attitudes and beliefs.
physiological responses that result in action.
the internal motivation for action.
the subconscious and its influence on overt behavior.
the influence of others on our emotional development.

problem.p: Believing that there is a relationship between two variables when there is no data to support it is an example of a:

choicegroup.label: Believing that there is a relationship between two variables when there is no data to support it is an example of a:
choicegroup.choice: negative correlation.
illusory correlation.
third variable problem.
confound.
causal relationship.

problem.p: Gertrude investigated the effects of two vocabulary learning strategies on subsequent word retention two weeks later. In this example, vocabulary learning strategy was the ________ variable and word retention was the ________ variable.

choicegroup.label: Gertrude investigated the effects of two vocabulary learning strategies on subsequent word retention two weeks later. In this example, vocabulary learning strategy was the ________ variable and word retention was the ________ variable.
choicegroup.choice: subject; participant
independent; dependent
dependent; independent
experimental; control
control; experimental

problem.p: Which of the following correlation coefficients best represents a moderate relationship indicative of fewer anxiety symptoms in people who report higher life satisfaction?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following correlation coefficients best represents a moderate relationship indicative of fewer anxiety symptoms in people who report higher life satisfaction?

problem.p: In this type of study design, neither the researchers nor the participants are aware of the group assignments.

choicegroup.label: In this type of study design, neither the researchers nor the participants are aware of the group assignments.
choicegroup.choice: control
double-blind
pilot
single-blind
randomly-assigned

problem.p: Pooja, a sociology major, believes that money is the key to happiness. Her friend Stephen, a psychology major, believes that good health is the key to happiness. Of the options below, which would be the most convincing way to resolve their disagreement?

choicegroup.label: Pooja, a sociology major, believes that money is the key to happiness. Her friend Stephen, a psychology major, believes that good health is the key to happiness. Of the options below, which would be the most convincing way to resolve their disagreement?
choicegroup.choice: They could ask their friends and see which perspective has the most support.
They could research peer-reviewed articles to see if either perspective is supported.
They could conduct a study with students on their campus to see which perspective has the most support.
They could research archives of newspapers, magazines, and other media to see if there are reports on the topic.
They could ask a professor for her or his opinion.

problem.p: Which of the following would be difficult to assess using empirical research?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following would be difficult to assess using empirical research?
choicegroup.choice: the abilities of non-human primates to learn and use sign language
whether the id, ego, or superego is most responsible for personality and behavior
the reaction time for participants to indicate they heard a ball drop on a table
whether a baby is crying because he is sad, hungry, or in pain
how a drug affects individuals diagnosed with major depression

problem.p: Which of the following is not a characteristic of a good hypothesis?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following is not a characteristic of a good hypothesis?
choicegroup.choice: It can be examined using empirical methods.
It is complex and explains as much about human behavior is possible
It is an “if-then” statement.
It is falsifiable.
It is based on the best available knowledge known to science.

problem.p: Which of the following is a limitation that would most seriously affect the generalizability of a set of research results?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following is a limitation that would most seriously affect the generalizability of a set of research results?
choicegroup.choice: the use of control groups
a small sample size
the use of operational definitions
the use of random assignment
the use of statistical analyses

problem.p: Dr. Mattar is interested in knowing more about brain injury to the occipital cortex, and he studies a handful of patients in great detail to better characterize their abilities and behaviors. This method of data collection would best be described as

choicegroup.label: Dr. Mattar is interested in knowing more about brain injury to the occipital cortex, and he studies a handful of patients in great detail to better characterize their abilities and behaviors. This method of data collection would best be described as
choicegroup.choice: surveys.
case studies.
correlational.
cross-sectional.
experiments.

problem.p: Melanie is interested in better understanding how couples behave in public places. She camps outside of a movie theatre and carefully notes how people who appear to be couples engage each other (i.e., amount of eye contact, whether or not they hold hands and kiss). This approach is most consistent with which of the following?

choicegroup.label: Melanie is interested in better understanding how couples behave in public places. She camps outside of a movie theatre and carefully notes how people who appear to be couples engage each other (i.e., amount of eye contact, whether or not they hold hands and kiss). This approach is most consistent with which of the following?
choicegroup.choice: case study
naturalistic observation
experiment
survey
self-report

problem.p: ________ examines the degree of consistency of observations by different observers.

choicegroup.label: ________ examines the degree of consistency of observations by different observers.
choicegroup.choice: Attrition percentage
Inter-rater reliability
Test-retest reliability
Inter-item validity
Convergent validity

problem.p: In scientific research, we often _______ from a ______ in order to make a _______ about others we have not studied in the current context.

choicegroup.label: In scientific research, we often _______ from a ______ in order to make a _______ about others we have not studied in the current context.
choicegroup.choice: generalization; sample; hypothesis
sample; population; generalization
population; sample; generalization
sample; population; hypothesis
population; sample; hypothesis

problem.p: A researcher wanted to assess whether viewpoints on decriminalization of marijuana for medical purposes change with age. Four groups of participants, ages 20, 30, 40, and 50, were asked whether they support marijuana use for medical purposes. What is one flaw of this design?

choicegroup.label: A researcher wanted to assess whether viewpoints on decriminalization of marijuana for medical purposes change with age. Four groups of participants, ages 20, 30, 40, and 50, were asked whether they support marijuana use for medical purposes. What is one flaw of this design?
choicegroup.choice: Longitudinal research is time-consuming and not worth the additional effort required.
Social and/or cultural differences amongst the various age cohorts may influence the results.
Marijuana has already been decriminalized in some places, eliminating the need for this work.
Recruitment could be a challenge because people of different ages are difficult to sample.
They are guaranteed to not have the same number of participants in each group.

problem.p: Which of the following studies best resembles a longitudinal design?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following studies best resembles a longitudinal design?
choicegroup.choice: Dr. Opus gathers health data from the Hospital and analyses health issues and longevity
Dr. Danielson studies a group of 3-month-old babies monthly for a total of three months
Dr. Parks studies a group of 20-year-olds and 40-year-olds and compares their political beliefs
Dr. Molson manipulates the age of his participants and examines its effect on maturity
Dr. Nguyen uses a survey method to examine the relationship between literacy and crime

problem.p: Which of the following studies best resembles an archival design?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following studies best resembles an archival design?
choicegroup.choice: Dr. Danielson studies a group of 3-month-old babies monthly for a total of three months
Dr. Opus gathers health data from the Hospital and analyses health issues and longevity
Dr. Parks studies a group of 20-year-olds and 40-year-olds and compares their political beliefs
Dr. Molson manipulates the age of his participants and examines its effect on maturity
Dr. Nguyen uses a survey method to examine the relationship between literacy and crime

problem.p: Which of the following would be the best example of a valid naturalistic observation study of driving behavior?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following would be the best example of a valid naturalistic observation study of driving behavior?
choicegroup.choice: carefully observing driving behavior during driving tests at a local driver’s licensing station
examining footage obtained from cameras set up unobtrusively on various street corners
requesting that passengers rate their driver’s behavior on a 1-5 scale at the end of the day
asking the drivers themselves to comment on their driving performance for the day
observing people’s performance on a driving simulator stationed in a laboratory

problem.p: Which of the following research designs will allow cause-and-effect conclusions?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following research designs will allow cause-and-effect conclusions?
choicegroup.choice: correlational
experimental
quasi-experimental
survey
longitudinal

problem.p: Stan’s psychology laboratory requires him to repeat classic experiments that have already been published to determine whether they produce the same results. This practice is called

choicegroup.label: Stan’s psychology laboratory requires him to repeat classic experiments that have already been published to determine whether they produce the same results. This practice is called
choicegroup.choice: inter-rater reliability.
replication.
reliability.
cross-sampling validity.
certainty testing.

problem.p: The possible range for a correlation coefficient is between

choicegroup.label: The possible range for a correlation coefficient is between
choicegroup.choice: –1 and 0.
0 and +1.
-1 and 0.

problem.p: Which of the following best reflects a real-world negative correlation?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following best reflects a real-world negative correlation?
choicegroup.choice: The amount of ice cream consumed daily and the amount of weight gained
The amount of water you drink and how thirsty you feel
Height and the amount of back problems you have during your lifetime
The quality of your diet (rated on a 0-100 scale) and your longevity
The temperature outside and the amount you sweat

problem.p: Which of the following represents a weak positive correlation?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following represents a weak positive correlation?

problem.p: Which of the following represents a strong negative correlation?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following represents a strong negative correlation?

problem.p: A ________ is a way to visualize the strength and direction of a correlation.

choicegroup.label: A ________ is a way to visualize the strength and direction of a correlation.
choicegroup.choice: bar graph
scatterplot
correlation coefficient
grouped histogram
p-value chart

problem.p: Research studies have shown that people who smoke cigarettes are more likely to get lung cancer than those who do not smoke. Drawing from this research alone, it is reasonable to conclude which of the following?

choicegroup.label: Research studies have shown that people who smoke cigarettes are more likely to get lung cancer than those who do not smoke. Drawing from this research alone, it is reasonable to conclude which of the following?
choicegroup.choice: Smoking causes lung cancer.
There is a relationship between smoking and lung cancer.
Smoking clearly contributes to lung cancer.
Those with lung cancer tend to start smoking because they are already sick.
There is insufficient evidence to demonstrate a link between smoking and lung cancer.

problem.p: A(n) ________ variable affects the variables of interest and may give the false impression of a causal relationship.

choicegroup.label: A(n) ________ variable affects the variables of interest and may give the false impression of a causal relationship.
choicegroup.choice: control
confound
dependent
independent
subject

problem.p: Sandra strongly believes that attending daycare is detrimental to children’s development so she decides to write her psychology term paper on this topic. She does a literature search and finds several sources supporting her opinion, but she finds that the majority of research indicates that children attending daycare experience healthy development. She ultimately writes a paper using the sources that find negative associations with daycare attendance. This is an example of ________.

choicegroup.label: Sandra strongly believes that attending daycare is detrimental to children’s development so she decides to write her psychology term paper on this topic. She does a literature search and finds several sources supporting her opinion, but she finds that the majority of research indicates that children attending daycare experience healthy development. She ultimately writes a paper using the sources that find negative associations with daycare attendance. This is an example of ________.
choicegroup.choice: type I error
confirmation bias
hawthorne effect
observer bias
demand characteristics

problem.p: A within-subjects experiment must involve a minimum of ________ participant group(s), and a between-subjects experiment must involve a minimum of _______ participant group(s).

choicegroup.label: A within-subjects experiment must involve a minimum of ________ participant group(s), and a between-subjects experiment must involve a minimum of _______ participant group(s).
choicegroup.choice: two; one
one; two
two; three
three; two
one; three

problem.p: The ________ group does not get the experimental treatment, and is needed to examine the potential effect of that treatment.

choicegroup.label: The ________ group does not get the experimental treatment, and is needed to examine the potential effect of that treatment.
choicegroup.choice: alternate
control
dependent
non-bias
independent

multiplechoiceresponse.label: A(n) ________ is a description of how the researchers will measure the variables of interest.

choicegroup.choice: experimental plan
hypothesis
operational definition
theory
placebo

multiplechoiceresponse.label: Sukhbir is interested in studying the way writing skills relate to gender. She believes that men are better at writing than women are. She administers an essay exam to a group of subjects, and grades them herself. Because of her expectation that men will do better on this exam than women, her grading may not be fair. What form of bias is likely to affect her behavior?

choicegroup.choice: availability bias
framing effect bias
participant bias
the placebo effect
confirmation bias

problem.p: Carter and Madison are five years old and they both say that are sick. Their father gives them a “special medicine” (a sugary gummy bear) and immediately after taking it, the kids report feeling better. Their improvement is most likely due to:

choicegroup.label: Carter and Madison are five years old and they both say that are sick. Their father gives them a “special medicine” (a sugary gummy bear) and immediately after taking it, the kids report feeling better. Their improvement is most likely due to:
choicegroup.choice: the active medicinal effects of the gummy bear
the placebo effect
practice effects
between-group variability
attrition

multiplechoiceresponse.label: The ________ are selected and measured by the experimenter to examine the effect of experimenters manipulation.

choicegroup.choice: confounding variable(s)
dependent variable(s)
independent variable(s)
experimental variable(s)
subject variable(s)

problem.p: Devine et al. are interested in assessing whether active versus passive play causes a preference for sweet or salty foods in toddlers. They assign groups of children to either an active play, passive play, or no play group and record their food choices when presented with a variety of sweet and salty foods. In this study, ________ is the independent variable and ________ is the control group.

choicegroup.label: Devine et al. are interested in assessing whether active versus passive play causes a preference for sweet or salty foods in toddlers. They assign groups of children to either an active play, passive play, or no play group and record their food choices when presented with a variety of sweet and salty foods. In this study, ________ is the independent variable and ________ is the control group.
choicegroup.choice: active play; passive play
type of play; no play
food choice; no play
no play; type of play
sweet food; salty food

problem.p: Harrison et al. are conducting a study assessing the ability of depressed versus non-depressed participants to remember negative emotions in a short story about a family whose car breaks down. They plan to ask participants to read the story and then make a list of the emotions expressed in the story. In this example, negative emotions are the

choicegroup.label: Harrison et al. are conducting a study assessing the ability of depressed versus non-depressed participants to remember negative emotions in a short story about a family whose car breaks down. They plan to ask participants to read the story and then make a list of the emotions expressed in the story. In this example, negative emotions are the
choicegroup.choice: independent variable.
dependent variable.
operational definition.
significant variable.
confounding variables.

problem.p: Which of the following is false regarding random sampling and random group assignment?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following is false regarding random sampling and random group assignment?
choicegroup.choice: it improves the researcher’s ability to generalize their findings
it may weaken any effect that the independent variable has on the participants
it ensures that each participant has a fair opportunity to be in any of the conditions
it increases the likelihood that the groups reflect the variability in the population
it helps protect against favoritism for some participants

problem.p: What is one task that a peer reviewer is not encouraged to do?

choicegroup.label: What is one task that a peer reviewer is not encouraged to do?
choicegroup.choice: conducting his or her own research in the same subject area
take the ideas from articles they review and use them as if they are their own
looking for potential flaws in the way a study was conducted
suggesting additional research or statistical analyses
verifying that the research meets ethical standards

problem.p: Peer reviewers are essential to the scientific process because they

choicegroup.label: Peer reviewers are essential to the scientific process because they
choicegroup.choice: push through work that is consistent with previous research
help ensure quality control in reporting scientific findings.
they control the only way that science is shared: through scientific articles
approve research done by top researchers, which is the primary way we advance science
allow for a researcher’s friends to give their “stamp of approval” on their work

problem.p: Suppose Dr. Boyd finds a very interesting result about the relationship between brain stimulation and recovery from stroke. But, when she tries to find the same result again in three subsequent studies, she is unable to do so. It is fair to say that her initial finding was:

choicegroup.label: Suppose Dr. Boyd finds a very interesting result about the relationship between brain stimulation and recovery from stroke. But, when she tries to find the same result again in three subsequent studies, she is unable to do so. It is fair to say that her initial finding was:
choicegroup.choice: lacking a sampling bias
not reliable
not actually statistically significant
suffering from a confirmation bias
more valid than her subsequent studies

problem.p: Some studies that cannot ethically be conducted as experiments with typical human participants are

choicegroup.label: Some studies that cannot ethically be conducted as experiments with typical human participants are
choicegroup.choice: actually possible to test with participants from prison populations.
possible to test with animal studies.
actually ethical in the sense that scientific knowledge is more important that participant welfare.
not possible to test with empirical methods.
possible to test with college students.

problem.p: Which of the following is the most commonly used subjects in animal research?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following is the most commonly used subjects in animal research?
choicegroup.choice: cats
rats
rhesus monkeys
pigeons
pigs

problem.p: _______ leans on the fact that the data have already been collected, and _______ allows you to collect large amounts of data with relative ease.

choicegroup.label: _______ leans on the fact that the data have already been collected, and _______ allows you to collect large amounts of data with relative ease.
choicegroup.choice: Naturalistic observation; experiments
Archival research; surveys
Correlational research; experiments
Archival research; experiments
Correlational research; surveys

problem.p: American researchers studying the effects of physical attractiveness on compliance wish to expand the cross-cultural generalizability of their findings to a Lebanese population. They travel to Lebanon and recruit local residents, whom the American researchers rate as attractive or unattractive, to act as experimental confederates. However, they are unable to replicate their research findings in the Lebanese sample. Which of the following is the most compelling reason for why this might be so?

choicegroup.label: American researchers studying the effects of physical attractiveness on compliance wish to expand the cross-cultural generalizability of their findings to a Lebanese population. They travel to Lebanon and recruit local residents, whom the American researchers rate as attractive or unattractive, to act as experimental confederates. However, they are unable to replicate their research findings in the Lebanese sample. Which of the following is the most compelling reason for why this might be so?
choicegroup.choice: Inter-rater reliability cannot be assessed with the Lebanese sample.
There may be differences in standards of attractiveness between the different cultures.
Language barriers prevent research studies from being used in other countries.
Americans are significantly less attractive than those who are Lebanese.
Researchers outside the United States are held to different standards than Americans.

problem.p: Longitudinal research is important to psychology because it allows us to track how someone changes over time. However, collecting longitudinal data is made more difficult by the fact that some people may not complete the study for known or unknown reasons, a problem known as:

choicegroup.label: Longitudinal research is important to psychology because it allows us to track how someone changes over time. However, collecting longitudinal data is made more difficult by the fact that some people may not complete the study for known or unknown reasons, a problem known as:
choicegroup.choice: selective participation.
attrition.
the cohort effect.
limited generalization.
participant weakness.

problem.p: Magali is interested in studying happiness. She defines happiness as “how a person rates their happiness on a scale of 1-5, where “1” is the least happy and “5” is the most happy. When she compares her work to already published studies, she finds that it agrees with some work and disagrees with other work. Given what you’ve read here, which of the following is least likely to be true?

choicegroup.label: Magali is interested in studying happiness. She defines happiness as “how a person rates their happiness on a scale of 1-5, where “1” is the least happy and “5” is the most happy. When she compares her work to already published studies, she finds that it agrees with some work and disagrees with other work. Given what you’ve read here, which of the following is least likely to be true?
choicegroup.choice: She may be using a different operational definition than other researchers.
Her work is accurate but every study that conflicts with hers is inaccurate.
Her happiness results may be true in her sample, but not in other samples.
She may be comparing her study to studies that are different in kind, making the comparison unreasonable.
Her operationalization of happiness may not properly capture happiness.

problem.p: An upper-level psychology class is conducting an experiment on racial prejudice that involves having participants rate the likeability of faces in a set of photos. However, they tell participants that the study is about the effects of aging on likeability. When participants are finished, they are thanked for their time and leave the experiment. Debriefing is always an important practice, and is especially important here because this study involved _______.

choicegroup.label: An upper-level psychology class is conducting an experiment on racial prejudice that involves having participants rate the likeability of faces in a set of photos. However, they tell participants that the study is about the effects of aging on likeability. When participants are finished, they are thanked for their time and leave the experiment. Debriefing is always an important practice, and is especially important here because this study involved _______.
choicegroup.choice: upper-level psychology students
deception
a contentious topic
likeability
reviewing photographs

problem.p: ________ can be used to assess ________.

choicegroup.label: ________ can be used to assess ________.
choicegroup.choice: Reliability; validity
Statistical analyses; reliability
Dependent variables; independent variables
Validity; reliability
Correlation; causality

problem.p: The ________ variable measures the effects of the _______ variable.

choicegroup.label: The ________ variable measures the effects of the _______ variable.
choicegroup.choice: control; dependent
dependent; independent
independent; dependent
dependent; confound
confound; dependent

problem.p: The only study design that allows you to examine whether there is a cause-and-effect relationship between two variables is a(n) ________.

choicegroup.label: The only study design that allows you to examine whether there is a cause-and-effect relationship between two variables is a(n) ________.
choicegroup.choice: correlational design
experiment
archival analysis
survey
meta-analysis

problem.p: Which of the following is false regarding animal research?

choicegroup.label: Which of the following is false regarding animal research?
choicegroup.choice: A different ethics board evaluates animal research compared to human research
Animal research is done whenever is it the most financially beneficial to the researcher
The goal of researchers is to phase out the use of animals as soon as possible
When alternative methods to animal research are developed, they should be favored
Researchers must always work to promote the welfare of animals and to minimize any pain or discomfort wherever possible

problem.p: A major advantage of case studies is the

choicegroup.label: A major advantage of case studies is the
choicegroup.choice: improved generalizability.
detailed information.
a larger sample size.
no experimenter bias.
the ease of data collection.

problem.p: The commonly accepted statistical threshold for data not occurring by chance is p = _______

choicegroup.label: The commonly accepted statistical threshold for data not occurring by chance is p = _______

p.b: Answer both of the following two questions. Note that it is not sufficient to answer a question by merely listing facts. You should present a coherent argument based on an analysis of the questions and use appropriate psychological terminology.* Your answers should be presented in sentences, and the sentences should be clear enough for your meaning to come through. Spelling and grammatical mistakes do not reduce your score, but spelling must be close enough so that the reader is convinced of the word.

div.p: Note: This section should take you 50 minutes (although you won't be penalized for going over that suggested time limit)--that is how much time you would have to complete the 2 free response questions on the AP® Psychology Exam. Accordingly, if you would like to get a sense of how well you are pacing yourself on this free response component of the exam, press the 'start timer' button below.

Also note: This section is worth 16.67% of your grade for the final exam in this course (on the actual AP® Psychology Exam the free response questions are worth 33.33% of your grade), or 10% of your final grade in the course.

Also note: In this course, you will be assessing your own responses to the following free response questions. In subsequent courses in this AP® Psychology course sequence, you may be asked to assess your peers responses and they will be asked to assess your responses--much as you did with the discussion questions in this course (but with a more complex rubric).
*These first two sentences were adapted from the directions for the free response component of the 2007 AP® Psychology Exam

body.div: During the AP® Psychology exam, you will have 50 minutes to finish this component of the final exam. A timer has been placed here so you can gauge how long it takes you to complete this portion of the exam. Note that you will not be penalized for going over that time limit in this course (though you would not receive additional time on the AP® Psychology exam).

prompt.description: Suppose you hear from your friends that a certain widely prescribed drug (Drug A52) helps improve their ability to study, and thus their academic achievement. You become interested in this and so you join a laboratory and set out to design a study to examine this potential relationship. 1. Consider how a case study and a correlational method would each help you address your question, taking care to note one key strength and one key weakness for each method. 2. Suppose you decide to design an experiment to test this phenomenon. Articulate how you would do this, clarifying your (a) hypothesis, (b) independent variable, (c) dependent variable, and (d) how you would assign participants in your study. Make sure to address how you would control for (e) the placebo effect and (f) practice effects. 3. Suppose you’ve collected your data and done the appropriate statistical analyses on it. If the p-value was p = .08, what would this mean for your hypothesis given the standard statistical convention?

criterion.name: Ideas
criterion.label: Part 1
criterion.prompt:
What follows are examples of advantages and disadvantages of case studies vs. correlational studies. Note that other potential advantages or disadvantages might be reasonable responses as well.
"Case Study. Advantage: You would be able to study someone using that drug in great detail, allowing you to thoroughly examine the effects on the person. Disadvantage: The participant(s) in the case study may not resemble the greater population, limiting your ability to generalize.
Correlational Study. Advantage: We often informally observe relationships in the world but a correlational study allows us to formalize it as real, as opposed to taking your friend’s word for it. Disadvantage: You would not be able to confirm a causal relationship between the drug and cognition (i.e., does the drug make people smarter, or do smarter people take the drug? Or is there a confound variable at play?), as correlation and causation are not the same thing."

option.name: Poor
option.label: No Points
option.explanation: Doesn't provide the advantages or disadvantages for either approach.

option.name: Fair
option.label: Poor
option.explanation: Provides only one reasonable advantage or disadvantage for one of the approaches.

option.name: Good
option.label: Fair
option.explanation: Provides only two reasonable advantages and/or disadvantages for one or both of the approaches.

option.label: Good
option.explanation: Provides only three reasonable advantages and/or disadvantages for the two approaches.

option.label: Very Good
option.explanation: Provides a reasonable advantage and a disadvantage for each of the approaches.

criterion.label: Part 2
criterion.prompt:
What follows is an example of a comprehensive response to this part of the question.
"a. Taking Drug A52 improves academic achievement. Predicting that it worsens cognition would not be appropriate here given the initial observations. b. Two groups would be necessary: an experimental group that will take Drug A52, and a control group that does not. c. Academic achievement could be measured a variety of different ways, such as performance on an exam, a course grade, or even their grade point average for a term. Importantly, you should collect data before any experimental manipulation to ensure that both groups are starting out at the same level, as to make a fair comparison later on. d. You would want to use random selection and assignment to ensure that all who were interested had an equal opportunity to participate, and to be in either the experimental or control condition. e. Use of a control group would help control for the placebo effect (getting better because of the mental expectation) because that expectation should exist for both groups. If the experimental group performs superior to the control group, we can be sure that it isn’t due to the placebo effect. f. Use of a control group also helps control for any practice effects (getting better because you’ve done the test before) because both groups will have been examined before any potential treatment, and after. If the experimental group performs superior to the control group, we can be sure that it isn’t due to practice effects."

option.label: No Points
option.explanation: Didn't answer any of the subcomponents (i.e., a-f) of this part of the question.

option.label: Very Poor
option.explanation: Provided a reasonable answer to only one of the subcomponents (i.e., a-f) of this part of the question.

option.label: Poor
option.explanation: Provided reasonable answers to only two of the subcomponents (i.e., a-f) of this part of the question.

option.label: Fair
option.explanation: Provided reasonable answers to only three of the subcomponents (i.e., a-f) of this part of the question.

option.label: Adequate
option.explanation: Provided reasonable answers to four of the subcomponents (i.e., a-f) of this part of the question.

option.label: Good
option.explanation: Provided reasonable answers to five of the subcomponents (i.e., a-f) of this part of the question.

option.label: Very Good
option.explanation: Provided reasonable answers to six of the subcomponents (i.e., a-f) of this part of the question.

option.label: Excellent
option.explanation: Provided reasonable answers to all of the subcomponents (i.e., a-f) of this part of the question.

criterion.label: Part 3
criterion.prompt:
What follows is an example of a solid response to this part of the question.
"Because the critical p-value is p = .05, we must conclude that Drug A52 does not significantly boost academic achievement."

option.label: No Points
option.explanation: Doesn't provide a response, or provides an incorrect response (e.g., states that Drug A52 significantly boosts academic achievement).

option.label: Very Good
option.explanation: Provides the correct response.

criterion.label: Sentences and Spelling
criterion.prompt: Answers were presented in sentences, and the sentences were clear enough for your meaning to come through. Spelling and grammatical mistakes do not reduce your score, but spelling must be close enough so that the reader is convinced of the word.

option.label: No Points
option.explanation: Didn't use sentences in the response and also had one or more spelling errors that were serious enough that it made it difficult for the reader to understand the meaning of the response.

option.label: Poor
option.explanation: Didn't use sentences in the response or had one or more spelling errors that were serious enough that it made it difficult for the reader to understand the meaning of the response.

option.label: Very Good
option.explanation: Used sentences in the response and there were no spelling errors that were serious enough to obscure the meaning of the response.

rubric.feedbackprompt: (Optional) What aspects of this response stood out to you? What did it do well? How could it be improved?

prompt.description: The aims and objects of psychological inquiry have undergone various changes over time. (a) Define each of the approaches below, (b) explain how each would be applied to an emotional experience (e.g., anger), and (c) identify one limitation per approach. 1) Structuralism 2) Functionalism 3) Behaviorism 4) Biological psychology

criterion.label: Part 1: Structuralism
criterion.prompt:
What follows is an example of a correct definition for Structuralism, an application of Structuralism and a limitation of Structuralism. Note that other potential applications or limitations might be reasonable responses as well.
"Structuralism. Analyzing the individual elements of the mind with the goal of understanding how they come together in a more complex way. Application: When a person feels anger, they should carefully reflect upon the experiences they are having (introspection), and carefully document their understanding of the process. Limitations: It is highly subjective and cannot be objectively confirmed; internal behavior is not measurable; the practice is reductionist in nature and thus may oversimplify how things work."

option.label: No Points
option.explanation: Doesn't provide any response or provides an incorrect response for this part of the question.

option.label: Poor
option.explanation: Provides only one of the following for this part of the question: (1) a correct definition; (2) a reasonable application; or (3) a reasonable limitation.

option.label: Fair
option.explanation: Provides two of the following for this part of the question: (1) a correct definition; (2) a reasonable application; or (3) a reasonable limitation.

option.label: Very Good
option.explanation: Provides all of the following for this part of the question: (1) a correct definition; (2) a reasonable application; and (3) a reasonable limitation.

criterion.label: Part 2: Functionalism
criterion.prompt:
What follows is an example of a correct definition for Functionalism, an application of Functionalism and a limitation of Functionalism. Note that other potential applications or limitations might be reasonable responses as well.
"Functionalism. Mental functions should be evaluated based on their utility for survival. Application: Perhaps anger occurs when we feel that we are not being given a fair chance to have access to resources that we feel entitled to, which could then threaten our well-being. Anything that links to the evolutionary significance of anger is acceptable. Limitation. Not as testable as empirical methods."

option.label: No Points
option.explanation: Doesn't provide any response or provides an incorrect response for this part of the question.

option.label: Poor
option.explanation: Provides only one of the following for this part of the question: (1) a correct definition; (2) a reasonable application; or (3) a reasonable limitation.

option.label: Fair
option.explanation: Provides two of the following for this part of the question: (1) a correct definition; (2) a reasonable application; or (3) a reasonable limitation.

option.label: Very Good
option.explanation: Provides all of the following for this part of the question: (1) a correct definition; (2) a reasonable application; and (3) a reasonable limitation.

criterion.label: Part 3: Behaviorism
criterion.prompt:
What follows is an example of a correct definition for Behaviorism, an application of Behaviorism and a limitation of Behaviorism. Note that other potential applications or limitations might be reasonable responses as well.
"Behaviorism. Defining psychology as the science of behavior. Application: When a person is angry, they are simply responding in a way that they have learned to do in the past. The key is to focus on behavior, not any aspect of thinking, as behaviorists rejected this as a valid form of study. Limitation. Many interesting things in psychology cannot be adequately explained by behaviorism alone (e.g., infants learning language, false memories, creativity)."

option.label: No points
option.explanation: Doesn't provide any response or provides an incorrect response for this part of the question.

option.label: Poor
option.explanation: Provides only one of the following for this part of the question: (1) a correct definition; (2) a reasonable application; or (3) a reasonable limitation.

option.label: Fair
option.explanation: Provides two of the following for this part of the question: (1) a correct definition; (2) a reasonable application; or (3) a reasonable limitation.

option.label: Very Good
option.explanation: Provides all of the following for this part of the question: (1) a correct definition; (2) a reasonable application; and (3) a reasonable limitation.

criterion.label: Part 4: Biological Psychology
criterion.prompt:
What follows is an example of a correct definition for Biological Psychology, an application of Biological Psychology and a limitation of Biological Psychology. Note that other potential applications or limitations might be reasonable responses as well.
"Biological Psychology. Linking biology to thinking and behavior. Application: When a person is angry, which parts of the brain mediate the psychological and behavioral response that they engage in? Note that anything that links the brain to behavior and/or the mind in an emotional context here is acceptable. Limitation. Nailing down the exact function of a brain region can be difficult because it could serve many different functions. Patient studies can be difficult when people don’t have damage to an area that you might like to study."

option.label: No Points
option.explanation: Doesn't provide any response or provides an incorrect response for this part of the question.

option.label: Poor
option.explanation: Provides only one of the following for this part of the question: (1) a correct definition; (2) a reasonable application; or (3) a reasonable limitation.

option.label: Fair
option.explanation: Provides two of the following for this part of the question: (1) a correct definition; (2) a reasonable application; or (3) a reasonable limitation.

option.label: Very Good
option.explanation: Provides all of the following for this part of the question: (1) a correct definition; (2) a reasonable application; and (3) a reasonable limitation.

criterion.label: Sentences and Spelling
criterion.prompt: Answers were presented in sentences, and the sentences were clear enough for your meaning to come through. Spelling and grammatical mistakes do not reduce your score, but spelling must be close enough so that the reader is convinced of the word.

option.label: No Points
option.explanation: Didn't use sentences in the response and also had one or more spelling errors that were serious enough that it made it difficult for the reader to understand the meaning of the response.

option.label: Poor
option.explanation: Didn't use sentences in the response or had one or more spelling errors that were serious enough that it made it difficult for the reader to understand the meaning of the response.

option.label: Very Good
option.explanation: Used sentences in the response and there were no spelling errors that were serious enough to obscure the meaning of the response.

rubric.feedbackprompt: (Optional) What aspects of this response stood out to you? What did it do well? How could it be improved?

option.label: Very Good
option.explanation: Provides all of the following for this part of the question: (1) a correct definition; (2) a reasonable application; and (3) a reasonable limitation.

criterion.label: Part 3: Behaviorism
criterion.prompt:
What follows is an example of a correct definition for Behaviorism, an application of Behaviorism and a limitation of Behaviorism. Note that other potential applications or limitations might be reasonable responses as well.
"Behaviorism. Defining psychology as the science of behavior. Application: When a person is angry, they are simply responding in a way that they have learned to do in the past. The key is to focus on behavior, not any aspect of thinking, as behaviorists rejected this as a valid form of study. Limitation. Many interesting things in psychology cannot be adequately explained by behaviorism alone (e.g., infants learning language, false memories, creativity)."

option.label: No points
option.explanation: Doesn't provide any response or provides an incorrect response for this part of the question.

option.label: Poor
option.explanation: Provides only one of the following for this part of the question: (1) a correct definition; (2) a reasonable application; or (3) a reasonable limitation.

option.label: Fair
option.explanation: Provides two of the following for this part of the question: (1) a correct definition; (2) a reasonable application; or (3) a reasonable limitation.

option.label: Very Good
option.explanation: Provides all of the following for this part of the question: (1) a correct definition; (2) a reasonable application; and (3) a reasonable limitation.

criterion.label: Part 4: Biological Psychology
criterion.prompt:
What follows is an example of a correct definition for Biological Psychology, an application of Biological Psychology and a limitation of Biological Psychology. Note that other potential applications or limitations might be reasonable responses as well.
"Biological Psychology. Linking biology to thinking and behavior. Application: When a person is angry, which parts of the brain mediate the psychological and behavioral response that they engage in? Note that anything that links the brain to behavior and/or the mind in an emotional context here is acceptable. Limitation. Nailing down the exact function of a brain region can be difficult because it could serve many different functions. Patient studies can be difficult when people don’t have damage to an area that you might like to study."

option.label: No Points
option.explanation: Doesn't provide any response or provides an incorrect response for this part of the question.

option.label: Poor
option.explanation: Provides only one of the following for this part of the question: (1) a correct definition; (2) a reasonable application; or (3) a reasonable limitation.

option.label: Fair
option.explanation: Provides two of the following for this part of the question: (1) a correct definition; (2) a reasonable application; or (3) a reasonable limitation.

option.label: Very Good
option.explanation: Provides all of the following for this part of the question: (1) a correct definition; (2) a reasonable application; and (3) a reasonable limitation.

criterion.label: Sentences and Spelling
criterion.prompt: Answers were presented in sentences, and the sentences were clear enough for your meaning to come through. Spelling and grammatical mistakes do not reduce your score, but spelling must be close enough so that the reader is convinced of the word.

option.label: No Points
option.explanation: Didn't use sentences in the response and also had one or more spelling errors that were serious enough that it made it difficult for the reader to understand the meaning of the response.

option.label: Poor
option.explanation: Didn't use sentences in the response or had one or more spelling errors that were serious enough that it made it difficult for the reader to understand the meaning of the response.

option.label: Very Good
option.explanation: Used sentences in the response and there were no spelling errors that were serious enough to obscure the meaning of the response.

rubric.feedbackprompt: (Optional) What aspects of this response stood out to you? What did it do well? How could it be improved?

stringresponse.label: Please provide a 1-2 sentence reflection on your performance on the free-response portion of the exam: What did you find particularly difficult? Where do you see room for improvement?

body.p: Note: After you have submitted your 1-2 sentence reflection above, please refresh the page to see the grading walkthrough video for the second free response question from the final exam. It will appear as a menu item located on the left hand menu entitled 'Free-Response Question 2: Grading Walkthrough'.

p.a: Download a copy of the slides used in the above video.

img.alt: Course 1 Banner

body.h2: Congratulations on completing Course 1 of the AP® Psychology Course Sequence!
body.p: We hope you enjoyed your time in the course and hope to see you in subsequent courses in the AP® Psychology Course Sequence.

If you found that you didn't do as well as you would have liked, please bear in mind that you can always redo this course for free. All of the courses in the AP® Psychology Course Sequence are free and will remain open until the date of the AP® Psychology exam (i.e., May 1, 2017).

We ask that you please take the time to complete the subsequent survey (which will take you less than 5 minutes) and will offer you the opportunity to provide us with your feedback about your time in this course.
Thank you,
Dr. Steven Barnes and the rest of the UBCx AP® Psychology Course Team
We would like to learn more about your experience with this course to better understand our learners and continuously improve the course. Data may also be used for educational research purposes.
The data we collect is confidential and will not be used in any way that personally identifies you. The survey is designed to take less than 5 minutes of your time. Thank-you for your participation.

p.iframe: Your browser does not support IFrames.

img.alt: Course 2 Banner

body.p: Once again: thank you for your time in this course!
Please consider registering for the second course in the AP® Psychology Course Sequence: How the Brain Works. You can register for that second course here.
